However, the structure of the hydrate, which is a kind of ice-like crystalline solid, has not been determined. In this work, we report the structure of neon hydrate, which is the first example of a hydrate with a crystalline structure. The structure of the hydrate is similar to that of ice II, which is the most stable phase of water at high pressure and low temperature. The foundations of quantum theory are a major open problem in mathematics. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical approach to the foundations of quantum theory. The approach is based on a set of axioms that are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. The axioms are shown to be sufficient to characterize the category of continuous linear operators between Hilbert spaces. This provides a mathematical foundation for the theory of quantum states and the theory of quantum operations. The approach is also shown to be consistent with the principles of mathematical realism and locality.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasitic animals that are of great interest to evolutionary biologists because of their extreme reduction in body plan and gene content. Here, we report the results of a comparative analysis of the genomes of two myxozoans and a cnidarian parasite. Our results show that myxozoans are a sister group to the rest of the Myxozoa, and that they are one of the most reduced animal genomes known. This reduction is accompanied by a reduction in gene content and expression, suggesting that the myxozoan body plan was lost through a process of extreme degeneration. Our results provide insights into the molecular basis of the transition from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic myxozoan. (Less)

COVID-19 is a global pandemic that has caused millions of deaths worldwide. The virus that causes COVID-19, SARS-CoV-2, is able to evade the antiviral action of the immune system by blocking the nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are essential for the induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 uses a viral accessory protein, Orf6, to block nuclear import of the STAT1 and STAT2 proteins. We found that Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex and directly interacts with the Nup98-Rae1 complex to impair docking of the cargo-receptor complex and disrupt nuclear import. Our results unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the antiviral action of the immune system and may lead to the development of new antiviral strategies. Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of the proton channel. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits the proton channel will further our understanding of the proton channel and might provide valuable information for future drug development for the proton channel. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by the middle of the 21st century. Meeting the food demand of this population will become increasingly challenging as the Earth’s climate continues to warm. Earlier studies suggest that once the optimum growing temperature is exceeded, mean crop yields decline and the variability of yield increases even if interannual climate variability remains unchanged. Here, we use global datasets of maize production and climate variability combined with future temperature projections to quantify how yield variability will change in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. We find that as the global mean temperature increases, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation (CV) of maize yields increases almost everywhere to values much larger than present-day values. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation (SD) of yields and a decrease in mean yields. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of species-level identification of food plants. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large herbivores in semiarid African savanna. We found that the extent of dietary overlap between species was greater than expected by chance, and that species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption had the greatest overlap. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large herbivore assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results highlight the need for more comprehensive and species-level identification of food plants in future studies of large herbivore diets. (Abridged)

We surveyed more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. However, the length of the crisis is uncertain, and many businesses expect it to last longer than 3 mo. Many businesses are financially fragile, with only about 2 wk of cash on hand. Finally, many businesses expect to apply for loans under the CARES Act, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of pollution in the ocean. However, the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is far less than expected, and that the missing plastic debris is mostly removed by a size-selective sink. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the Solar System is one of the most important questions in astronomy. The age of the Solar System is determined by the age of the oldest meteorites. However, the age of the oldest meteorites is not known. We determined the age of the oldest meteorites, which are the Murchison CM2 meteorite, by analyzing presolar silicon carbide grains.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to increase the amount of energy available to the mother is a key component of the evolution of domestication and allonursing. Here, we show that the increase in energy availability is a major driver of the increase in reproductive output. We also show that the increase in energy availability is not the result of an increase in resource availability. Rather, the increase in energy availability is a result of the increase in the metabolic power of the mother.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects multiple brain regions. The disease is characterized by the presence of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected neurons. We show here that the inflammatory protease caspase-1 is expressed in the striatum of MSA patients and in the brains of MSA mice. Caspase-1 expression is increased in the brains of MSA patients with a clinical phenotype similar to that of MSA mice. Caspase-1 inhibition by the prodrug VX-765, which is well tolerated in patients with epilepsy, reduced α-syn pathology in MSA mice. VX-765 also preserved tyrosine hydroxylase-positive neurons in the substantia nigra of MSA mice. These results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in MSA by limiting α-syn accumulation. This would be a major step forward in the treatment of this orphan disease. (Show more)

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the interface between the circulatory system and the tissues of the body. It is a highly specialized cell layer that controls the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissues. The endothelium is also the first line of defense against infection and injury. This study reveals that the endothelium is a highly connected network of cells that is organized in a way that allows for rapid and robust communication between cells. This is important for the control of the many functions of the endothelium.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. In this paper, we describe the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 data, including traditional public health surveillance signals and many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. The COVIDcast API is intended to provide a valuable resource for policy makers, epidemiological modelers, and researchers in the United States and beyond.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes and are the target of a large number of drugs. The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the channel and is responsible for the specific binding of the ion. The activation gate is the part of the channel that opens and closes the channel. We have found that the activation gate can allosterically affect the selectivity filter. This allosteric communication is crucial for the proper functioning of the channel.

The gut microbiome of herbivores is a dynamic community that is constantly changing in response to the environment and the host. This study shows that anaerobic fungi, which are a major component of the gut microbiome, synthesize natural products that could regulate the composition of the microbiome. This finding has implications for the study of the gut microbiome and the development of new therapeutics.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social groups. We show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes individuals to become subordinate during a social encounter, directly influences social dominance and that this effect is mediated by mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. These findings have important implications for our understanding of the role of brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. Our results also highlight the importance of mitochondrial function in the establishment of social hierarchy and the low probability to become dominant associated with high anxiety. This may have important implications for the treatment of anxiety disorders. (PsycINFO Dataset)

This paper presents a digital synthesis approach to design and manufacture multifunctional structures with complex and programmable mechanical responses. The proposed approach is based on the digital synthesis of composite structures with multiple material phases, which are digitally designed to have distinct mechanical properties. The synthesized structures are manufactured via multimaterial fabrication, and their highly nonlinear responses are physically realized. The synthesized structures are highly programmable and can be easily modified to achieve different responses. The proposed approach can be extended to design and manufacture multifunctional structures with complex and programmable responses for a wide range of applications.

The hemoglobin system is a major target of the let-7 miRNA pathway. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a downstream element of the let-7 pathway and that it is expressed in the fetal period. We demonstrate that IGF2BP1 is a major contributor to the developmental silencing of hemoglobin expression in the adult. This is a major finding in the field of hemoglobin regulation, as it suggests that the let-7 pathway may be a major regulator of the hemoglobin system in humans.

Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide. Despite the advances in cancer treatment, the majority of patients do not respond to treatment and the disease progresses. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling pathway protects cancer cells from ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. This resistance is mediated by the activation of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. In addition, we found that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction results in near-complete tumor regression in preclinical models. These results suggest that the combination of ferroptosis induction and mTORC1 inhibition may be a promising strategy for cancer treatment. (Show more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of the prevention of heart failure. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are calcium channel blockers. However, these drugs are associated with a high risk of developing heart failure. This study reveals a mechanism of the action of these drugs, which may help to improve the safety of their use.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of old-growth forests and associated wildlife in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP has not been effective in reversing the decline of older forest-associated bird populations. The policy has, however, halted the decline of early-seral forests, which are important for many bird species. The NWFP is now being replaced by a new policy, the Pacific Landscape Conservation Cooperative, which will continue to protect older forests. Our findings highlight the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. This will be critical to the long-term conservation of birds and other species associated with old-growth forests. (Less)

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. Here, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This work provides a proof of concept for the use of computational predictions in the design of new antibiotics. (Show more)

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, which makes them difficult to train and apply in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is also easier to implement and train, and is more robust to changes in the training data. We believe that the proposed architecture will be useful for many image-processing problems in the future.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime has become ubiquitous in many countries. This study shows that this use has a negative impact on sleep, with implications for health and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a 129-ka event that is hypothesized to have been triggered by one or more bolide impacts. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope composition of the YDB is consistent with a terrestrial origin, and that the spherules are from a source in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America.

The role of CTLA-4 in the regulation of the immune response is well established. However, the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity is still controversial. Here, we show that the loss of CTLA-4 in adult mice results in the development of a variety of autoimmunity, which is not observed in congenital deficiency.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We reconstructed the evolutionary history of beetles, including the origins of plant feeding, using a comprehensive dataset of genes encoding microbial genes that beetles use to digest plant tissues. Our results suggest that the evolution of beetles was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that beetles use to digest plant tissues.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm to efficiently enhance antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. View Full-Text

We report a large-scale experiment that investigates the extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE). We find that, in the absence of CCE, larger populations do not enhance artifact performance. However, in the presence of CCE, larger populations do enhance artifact performance, but only under certain specific conditions.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia in the elderly. The strongest genetic risk factor for AD is the apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE is a protein that is involved in the metabolism of cholesterol and fat. APOE isoform is highly dependent on its function in AD susceptibility. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, which is highly dependent on APOE isoform. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration.

The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere of iron that is about 1,200 km in diameter and 1,300 km in radius. It is the only solid sphere in the universe. The formation of the inner core is one of the most important unsolved problems in geophysics. We show that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be a two-step process, which is different from the previous understanding. This new understanding provides a key factor in solving the long-standing paradox of the inner core.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that the brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA), is blunted in marijuana abusers. This blunted reactivity may contribute to the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors of marijuana abusers.
We show that the most powerful artificial neural networks can be used to understand the human brain.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it has been unstable. We show that this instability is due to the fact that the algorithms used to train DL models are not stable. We introduce a new class of algorithms that are stable and prove that they are sufficient for the existence of stable DL models. This is a major advance in the field.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. It is also a scientific scandal. The scientific community is currently debating the causes of the pandemic. One of the most prominent arguments is that people’s inability to understand exponential growth is the main cause of the pandemic. This argument is based on a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago. Despite its critical design flaws, this experiment is still widely cited. Here, we discuss the flaws of the experiment and show that they undermine its conclusion.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years. It is caused by two bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which are very similar in size, genome content, and gene content. However, they have different hosts, different pathogenic mechanisms, and different geographic distributions. This study shows that they are not the same species and that they have diverged from a common ancestor approximately 14 million years ago.

The entanglement dynamics of interacting quantum many-body systems is a long-standing open problem. Here, we show that the quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics, which is exact for integrable systems, leads to a complete understanding of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain and find excellent agreement with numerical simulations.

COVID-19 is a pandemic that has killed millions of people worldwide. The only available vaccine is based on the inactivated virus, which is not suitable for mass vaccination. Here, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine that is highly protective in a relevant animal model. This vaccine has the potential to be used in mass vaccination programs to combat the pandemic.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) was the longest and most devastating of the four pandemics of plague. It led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that of rodent transmission. Here, we show that human ectoparasites, such as fleas or lice, were the primary vectors of the disease during the Black Death (1347–1353). This finding challenges the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. Our results are based on a Bayesian approach, which allows us to quantify the uncertainty in our results. This approach is essential to understand the limitations of the models and to understand the uncertainty in the data. We hope that our results will contribute to a better understanding of the history of plague in Europe.

The evolution of the brain is one of the most important questions in biology. However, the evolution of brain size is not a good proxy for the evolution of brain power because it is biased by the evolution of body size. This study shows that the evolution of the brain is not only characterized by the increase in brain size but also by the increase in the number of neurons.

The role of TRAP1 in cancer has been the subject of intense debate. Here we show that TRAP1 is a metabolic regulator, and that its expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin is a key regulator of the dynamic actin cytoskeleton. It is known to sever actin filaments, but the mechanism by which it does so is not understood. Here, we show that ADF/cofilin can induce a mechanical torque on actin filaments, which enhances severing. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our results provide a mechanistic explanation for the role of ADF/cofilin in cells and may lead to the development of new strategies for controlling the dynamics of the actin cytoskeleton.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in soft drinks and other beverages. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings may help explain the increased prevalence of obesity in the United States and elsewhere. They also suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian people, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The population structure is also influenced by geography, suggesting that the history of Madagascar is not only the history of the settlement of the island but also the history of the mixing of the people who settled the island. This is a fundamental change in our understanding of the history of Madagascar.

We show that the content of social networks can influence the emotions of individuals. We find that the amount of positive content in a person’s News Feed influences the amount of positive content that person produces, and that the amount of negative content in a person’s News Feed influences the amount of negative content that person produces. These results suggest that the content of social networks can influence the emotions of individuals.

The ribosome is a complex molecular machine that is responsible for translating messenger RNA (mRNA) into proteins. The mRNA sequence is a key determinant of translation, but the ribosome can also be influenced by the presence of chemical modifications in the mRNA. In this work, we show that the most common mRNA modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), can have a modest impact on translation. Our results suggest that the presence of Ψ can alter the rate of translation and the decoding of mRNA codons. These findings have implications for understanding the role of mRNA modifications in the ribosome’s function and for the design of translation systems for therapeutic applications. (Show more)

This study shows that the feeling that the things one does in life are worthwhile is associated with a wide range of positive health and well-being outcomes. This finding has implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging and for the development of a more positive sense of life meaning.

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a well-known and important evolutionary phenomenon. Here, we show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is the primary driver of this phenomenon. We also show that the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is constrained by the energetic demands of the aquatic medium.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The virus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. We show that the temperature-dependent growth phenotype of rhinovirus is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature.

Bacteria use a variety of sensing systems to respond to environmental signals. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to detect the presence of surfaces. This mechanism is essential for the regulation of surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity.

The presence of pesticides in surface waters is a global problem. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global extent of pesticide contamination and its impact on aquatic biodiversity. We show that the presence of pesticides in surface waters is widespread and that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society. However, the role of animals in the spread of the virus is largely unknown. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to infection. Our findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a robust and proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This is especially important in light of the recent emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants of concern. Our study highlights the need for a more comprehensive understanding of the role of animals in the spread of the virus. (Show more)

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the causes of this problem and proposes solutions. We show that the benefits of hydropower are overestimated and the costs underestimated. We also show that the environmental and social impacts of dams are not well understood and that the benefits of dams are not well understood by the people living in the areas where they are built. We propose that the industry needs to change its practices and that governments need to play a more active role in the planning and construction of dams.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here, we show that soluble and oligomeric forms of amyloid-β (Aβ) are the most toxic amyloid species within the brain, and that they are responsible for the activation of neurons and the release of inflammatory factors. This neuron-specific inflammatory response may precede the formation of insoluble Aβ plaques and tau tangles, and may be a significant component in the AD pathogenesis.

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still debated. We present a detailed analysis of the faunal remains from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, and show that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was widespread at that site, predating the earliest evidence from Europe by at least a century. This finding has important implications for our understanding of the evolution of the chicken and its economic use.

The folding of large proteins is a major challenge in understanding the kinetics of protein folding. We have developed a method that allows the study of the kinetics of folding of a large protein at high structural resolution. We have applied this method to the maltose binding protein, which is known to fold through a native-like intermediate. The results show that the intermediate is formed in a fast step, followed by a slow step that is the major step of the folding process. The results also show that the intermediate is not the only step in the folding process, suggesting that the folding of large proteins is more complex than previously thought. (Show more)

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a key factor in the regulation of gene expression in bacteria. However, the mechanism by which this occurs is not well understood. Here, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing the cap structure from Np4-capped RNAs is also activated by stress, and that it prefers to remove the cap from Np4-capped RNAs over other forms of capped RNA. This unique mode of substrate recognition may be a key factor in the regulation of gene expression during stress.

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcomes. The mechanisms involved in the immunosuppression that occurs during sepsis are not fully understood. Here, we show that arginine, a key amino acid, is depleted in sepsis and that this depletion is associated with the expansion of myeloid-derived suppressor cells (MDSCs) and regulatory T cells (Tregs). We also show that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is more effective than arginine in restoring T cell function and proliferation and in decreasing the expansion of Tregs and MDSCs. These results suggest that citrulline could be a promising therapeutic strategy for the treatment of sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing clinical studies with citrulline in sepsis. The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers. Our analysis highlights the importance of the historical impact of humans on the biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. They are essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in which a system, when perturbed, returns to a state of activity at a rate that is proportional to the magnitude of the perturbation. This paper is about a continuous model of SOC, which is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe the model and its relation to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena. We also discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a promising material for electronic and photonic applications. However, its bandgap is too large for many applications. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under mechanical strain, and that the bandgap can be reduced to a few eV. This opens up opportunities for diamond to be used in a wide range of applications, including quantum applications.
This study describes the structure and antifungal activity of a unique NCR peptide. It also illustrates the potential of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and demonstrate that the female reproductive tract is a major source of molecular continuity between males and females. Our research provides a foundation for understanding the molecular basis of sperm–FRT interactions and the extent to which the female reproductive tract contributes to the viability of sperm. This work will be of interest to the broader scientific community and will be useful for the study of sperm–FRT interactions in other species.

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, helping blood to clot. In some people, the protein is not enough, and they have a bleeding disorder. We show that the protein can be switched between two states, one of which is more effective at binding platelets. This is important for understanding the disease, and for treating it.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that are essential for human health. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been difficult to study. This study provides a comprehensive database of human-associated viruses, which is a critical resource for future research.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the ACI process and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to observe the diurnal aerosol loading and cloud microphysical properties simultaneously. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature history of the Earth is a key factor in understanding the evolution of life. The temperature of the Earth’s surface has been estimated from the isotopic composition of marine cherts to have decreased from 70 ± 15 °C in the Archean to the present ∼15 °C. However, this estimate has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding oceanic isotopic compositions, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. We here present thermostability measurements of ancestral enzymes, which provide an independent method by which to assess the temperature history inferred from the isotopic evidence. Our results suggest that Earth’s surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. (Abridged)

K+ channels are the most abundant ion channels in the body and are involved in a wide range of physiological and pathological processes. They are also the targets of many drugs. The activation gate of K+ channels is a critical site for drug binding and is the focus of many studies. However, the activation gate of the large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel is not a classic bundle-crossing activation gate and shows no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s activation gate is spatially overlapped with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. This finding provides a new perspective for the study of K+ channel activation and C-type inactivation. It also provides a potential target for the development of drugs and gene therapy for the treatment of diseases associated with K+ channel dysfunction. (Show more)

Malaria is a disease that affects millions of people worldwide. The parasite, Plasmodium, invades the human red blood cell (RBC) to complete its life cycle. The invasion process is a complex event, and the role of the parasite’s surface proteins in this process has been extensively studied. Here, we show that the malaria parasite’s erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175) alters the biophysical properties of the RBC, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This finding suggests that the malaria parasite is not simply a mechanical force, but rather a complex system that works in concert with the host cell to facilitate invasion. This work provides a new perspective on the invasion process and may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of malaria. (Show more)

Diamond is a promising material for electronic and photonic applications. However, its bandgap is too large for many applications. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under mechanical strain, and that the bandgap can be reduced to a few eV. This opens up opportunities for diamond to be used in a wide range of applications, including quantum applications.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks are associated with decreases in ambient humidity. However, the impact of low humidity on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection and may lead to the development of strategies to mitigate the impact of influenza virus disease. The brain’s processing of language is often assumed to be based on a tree-like structure of nested phrases. However, whether and how the brain builds such structures is largely unknown. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases suddenly whenever words can be merged into a phrase. This merge operation is consistent with a neural implementation of a bottom-up or left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This may be a fundamental property of the language system.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major regulator of development and homeostasis. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are not only similar at the protein level but also genetically redundant. We show that the two forms of Axin are differentially regulated on the transcriptional and proteostatic level, which can be used to regulate the two forms of Axin in a tissue-specific manner. This may be a common mechanism in other redundant gene pairs in vertebrates.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region in the brain that regulates feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We show that this effect is mediated by a circuit that includes dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area (VTA). However, we also show that this circuit is not required for the eating response, suggesting that the LH circuit may contribute to overeating and contribute to the development of obesity.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and bacteria is a key component of sustainable agriculture. Here, we have developed a system for the plant-controlled regulation of the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis, which may be used to control the activity of bacteria in the symbiosis and to deliver biologically fixed nitrogen in agriculture.

We study the impact of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon. The program was randomly assigned to 39 of 76 communities. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. The results suggest that the program may contribute to sustainable forest management.

Hearing is a fundamental sense of all animals, including mammals, birds, reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body of animals. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is outsourced to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

COVID-19 is a global pandemic that has killed millions of people worldwide. Vaccines are the most effective way to control the pandemic. However, the high cost of the currently available vaccines may limit their global access. This study reports a recombinant protein vaccine candidate that can be manufactured at a low cost and can be used to produce billions of doses annually. The vaccine candidate is based on a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein, which mediates viral entry to cells. The variant exhibits high-affinity binding to the receptor, high-yield manufacturability, and enhanced immunogenicity compared to the currently used variant. The vaccine candidate can be used to produce virus-like particles (VLPs) that can be used to treat COVID-19 in hamsters. These results provide a promising approach for the development of a low-cost, high-yield, and effective vaccine for COVID-19. This approach can be extended to other infectious diseases. The vaccine candidate can also be used to develop a vaccine for future emerging infectious diseases.

Neuroblastoma is the most common solid tumor in children. The majority of neuroblastoma patients is treated with surgery and chemotherapy. However, the majority of patients relapse and the survival rate is still low. In this study, we show that zebrafish ALK/Ltk signaling is involved in the development of iridophores, neural crest-derived pigment cells. We further show that zebrafish ALK/Ltk signaling is required for the development of iridophores. Our results provide evidence that ALK/Ltk signaling is involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues and may contribute to the development of neuroblastoma. Thus, our results may help to understand the development of neuroblastoma and to develop new therapeutic strategies.

The emergence of plague as a devastating disease in human history is a well-known story. However, the history of this pathogen is still largely unknown, and the origin of plague is still a matter of debate. Here, we present a large dataset of ancient Yersinia pestis genomes, which allowed us to explore the diversity of this pathogen during the formative years of its evolution. Our results show that the emergence of plague was a process that took place over millennia, with a single lineage persisting for thousands of years without significant diversification. This study also reveals the presence of a flea-adapted form of plague in Iberia, which was previously only found in the Caucasus and the Volga regions. These data provide insights into the early evolution and ecology of plague, which can help us to understand the origins of this disease and its impact on human history. (Less)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—and their support for Donald Trump. We found that women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. They have implications for understanding the political and social consequences of the endorsement of HM.

The fate of soil organic carbon (SOC) in agricultural systems is a critical issue for the sustainability of agriculture and the global carbon cycle. This study shows that the management of annual cropping systems on native grassland soils can have a significant impact on SOC storage and the distribution of SOC between particulate and mineral-associated fractions. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester carbon and provide a framework for the development of climate-smart agriculture.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to cause disease outbreaks in humans. We used this framework to identify the top 12 wildlife viruses with the greatest spillover potential. The resulting database, SpillOver, is publicly available and can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This work provides a foundation for the development of a global system to monitor and respond to emerging viral threats.

Nectar is the reward that most plants offer to pollinators for visitation. The color of this reward is often a key factor in the success of pollination. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of the blood-red flower of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid. We also identify a mechanism for the production of this color in other plants. This work provides evidence for the convergence of this trait in two different families of plants, and suggests that the red color of nectar is a key factor in the success of pollination.

We present a study of the genetic history of Europe during the Early Medieval period. We show that women, in particular, had a very high genetic heterogeneity, which included signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. This heterogeneity is particularly striking in women with artificial skull deformations, which suggests that they also differed in visible characteristics. In addition, many functional variants were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a pathogen that currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings provide insights into the origin and evolution of MERS-CoV and its bat coronavirus ancestors. They also suggest that the use of DPP4

We report the use of a cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to identify the regional pathogen landscape in a resource-scarce setting. We found that vector-borne pathogens were the most common clinical category, but that underappreciated zoonotic pathogens, such as Plasmodium knowlesi, leptospirosis, and coinfecting HIV, were also detected. This study highlights the importance of pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings and the potential for cloud-based metagenomic sequencing to identify emerging pathogens. This approach can be used to better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This study provides a foundation for future studies in resource-scarce settings. (Less)

The human genome is replicated in a discontinuous manner, with the DNA being replicated in Okazaki fragments. The process of Okazaki fragment synthesis is highly processive and requires the formation of a stable pol δ holoenzyme with the sliding clamp. Here, we report the results of a series of kinetic analyses that reveal that the pol δ holoenzyme is not stable and dissociates from the sliding clamp after each Okazaki fragment is synthesized. This finding has profound implications for the process of Okazaki fragment synthesis and the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme may be a key determinant of the fidelity of the lagging strand replication.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In this paper, we report the first in vitro evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme, which can replicate RNA from an RNA template. This is a major step toward the reconstruction of RNA-based life in the laboratory.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a useful indicator of the economic well-being of the residents of those neighborhoods.

The clinical characteristics of severe and critical COVID-19 patients are analyzed, and the immune characteristics of these patients are also studied. The results show that the immune system of severe and critical COVID-19 patients is suppressed, and the immune response is weakened. The results also show that tocilizumab, which targets the interleukin 6 pathway, can improve the clinical condition of severe and critical COVID-19 patients immediately. Therefore, tocilizumab is an effective treatment for severe and critical COVID-19 patients.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal that can cause disease. The ability of fungi to sequester copper is well established, but the role of fungal natural products in copper homeostasis is unknown. We report the discovery of a copper-binding fungal natural product, xanthocillin, and demonstrate that this compound has antimicrobial properties. The existence of this copper-binding fungal natural product suggests a role for these compounds in the regulation of copper homeostasis and the control of interactions with competing microbes. This discovery has implications for the study of fungal physiology and the control of fungal disease. (Read more)

Tridymite is a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of silica, which is a major component of many igneous rocks. It is rare on Earth, but abundant in the Martian crust. The detection of tridymite in a laminated mudstone at the base of the sedimentary sequence at the base of the “Lake Gale” sequence is a significant discovery, as it provides evidence for the presence of a magma ocean on early Mars and the potential for the existence of a magma ocean on early Earth.

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of forests and agriculture, and the geographic distribution of frost events is changing in response to climate warming. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is linked to the evolutionary history of the species involved. Our findings can help decision-makers to adapt to the changing risk of frost damage.

Th17 cells are central to the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the role of these cells in the development of disease is not well understood. Here, we show that the development of colitis requires the transition of a subset of Th17 cells to Th1-like cells and that this process is dependent on the expression of the transcription factor T-bet. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis. Thus, targeting Th17 cells may be a useful therapeutic strategy for the treatment of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, and the disease mechanism is not fully understood. Here, we report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS, which can be used to study the disease mechanism and to screen for drugs to treat the disease. This method will accelerate ALS research and development of therapeutics.

The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays a critical role in the transmission of human pathogens. We now show that the bacterium Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the composition of the gut microbiota and facilitates the colonization of the tick. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of how a human pathogen exploits an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This knowledge will be useful for the development of strategies to control the transmission of human pathogens by ticks. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most iconic and enigmatic stories in vertebrate evolution. The discovery of a new basal member of the group of birds with a short tail (Pygostylia) provides new insights into the origin of the modern avian body plan.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the climate system without understanding the role of water vapor. This is because water vapor is the most important greenhouse gas, and it is also the most important ingredient in clouds, which are the most important absorbers of solar radiation.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and many of them have the ability to change color. This ability is important for animals to adapt to their environment, and it is also important for humans to appreciate the beauty of nature. However, the molecular basis of color change in vertebrates is not well understood. In this study, we found that many vertebrates have a unique blue-green color, and we found that this color is due to the presence of a specific group of proteins. This discovery provides a new perspective on the evolution of color in vertebrates and may lead to the development of new color-based technologies. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a feature of many solid tumors, including breast cancer, and is associated with the development of cancer stem cells, which are responsible for tumor initiation and metastasis. We report that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which demethylates N6-methyladenosine (m6A) at the 3′-untranslated region (3′-UTR) of NANOG mRNA, which encodes a pluripotency factor. ALKBH5 expression is increased in breast cancer cells in response to hypoxia, and this results in enrichment of cancer stem cells, which are responsible for tumor initiation and metastasis. Thus, ALKBH5 may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer. This study provides a mechanism for the role of hypoxia in the development of breast cancer stem cells. (Show more)

The use of fetal animal skins in the production of parchment is a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, such as rabbit, but instead identified the use of more than one species of mammal in a single manuscript. This suggests that the production process allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness.

The Permian-Triassic extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age of the extinction and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics depend on an accurate and precise age model. We present a new age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dating of volcanic ash beds. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. Carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. Decamillenial to millennial level resolution of the mass extinction and its aftermath will permit a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion, and establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. The intestinal epithelium is the first line of defense against the environment. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is essential for the maintenance of intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORα deletion leads to the up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in intestinal epithelial cells (IECs), which in turn, results in the excessive activation of inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Our results suggest that RORα/histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3)-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). This study also provides a potential target for the treatment of IBD. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the immune system and for vaccine development. We have determined the structure of the spike protein in the open conformation, which is the most infectious, and in the closed conformation, which is the most prevalent in the current circulating virus population. We find that the open conformation is more prevalent in the current circulating virus population and that the D614G mutation is associated with a more open conformation. These results provide insights into the mechanism of action of the virus and may help to inform the development of vaccines and antiviral therapeutics. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that, in the absence of the pandemic, life expectancy at birth would have been 78.65 y in 2020, and at age 65 y, 82.18 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. These findings highlight the importance of addressing structural inequalities in health outcomes. (PsycINFO Dataset)

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry. They are also the key to understanding the chemistry of compounds. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become highly electropositive. These results are of fundamental importance for chemistry and for the understanding of the chemistry of compounds under pressure. They also provide a predictive model for the chemistry of elements under pressure. This work is a major advance in the field of chemical physics.

Fire is a key ecosystem process, but its effects on climate are poorly understood. We show that changes in human demography, rather than climate, are the dominant driver of global fire activity. This has important implications for the future of the carbon cycle, as well as for the role of fire in climate change.

The provision of nutrients to specific symbiotic microbes is a common feature of animal-microbe interactions. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are not well understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is the trigger for the maturation of a symbiotic organ and the subsequent delivery of chitin to the luminal bacteria. This glycan is provided only at night, when the host is quiescent, and is catabolized by the symbionts, which in turn modulates the environment of their habitat and enhances the production of bioluminescence. This study provides a mechanism by which the host can regulate the activities of its symbionts. (Show more)

Text data are ubiquitous and are increasingly being used to understand the world around us. However, the data are often unstructured, and the patterns of interest are often latent. We introduce a method to identify the topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We then apply the method to a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. We hope it will be useful to researchers in many fields.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the plague, and on the role of climate in the spread of this disease. It also provides a new approach to the study of the history of epidemics, which can be applied to other diseases and to other periods in history. (Less)

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and play a key role in the ecosystem. However, they are also a major prey item for a variety of predators. In the last few years, a disease has been observed that has led to the mass mortality of sea stars on the Pacific Coast of North America. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that it is the most likely cause of the mass mortality.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia, and the prognosis of patients with AML is poor. The identification of targets for the treatment of AML is therefore of great importance. In this study, we show that the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP; IL1R3) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We also show that an antibody targeting IL1RAP has strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. Furthermore, we demonstrate that the antibody can block interleukin 1 signaling and suppress the proliferation of primary human AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Thus, our results provide a basis for the development of new therapies for AML. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the population of Madagascar is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian people, with a limited contribution of Europeans and Middle Easterners. The admixture was recent, and the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. These results provide a better understanding of the history of Madagascar and the Indian Ocean region. They also provide a better understanding of the genetic history of the human species, and they provide a better understanding of the genetic structure of human populations.
