Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a protein that interacts with a membrane-bound enzyme and increases its activity. The protein also interferes with the ability of the RNA to repress two other genes. These results demonstrate that the protein interferes with the ability of the RNA to regulate the target genes and suggest that the protein may have evolved to interfere with the ability of the RNA to regulate other genes. This is an example of a protein that has evolved to have a regulatory role in addition to its protein-coding function.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm to efficiently enhance antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. View Full-Text

Crop experts are the primary source of information on the status of crops in the field. However, their assessments are subjective and categorical, and are not easily amenable to quantitative analysis. We show that the USDA Crop Progress and Condition survey, which is conducted by a large number of crop experts across the country, can be transformed into a continuous, probabilistic variable that can be used to monitor crop status and predict crop yields. We demonstrate that this index outperforms official forecasts released midseason by several weeks and provides earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields. This work provides a framework for the use of crop expert assessments in agricultural monitoring and forecasting. It also provides a new source of information for the agricultural community. Finally, it provides a valuable resource for the development of new applications in agriculture, such as the monitoring of crop health and the development of precision agriculture systems.

Language processing is a complex cognitive function that is thought to be supported by the maintenance of information in working memory. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is able to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. In this study, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. This work is critical to improving our understanding of the global carbon cycle and the role of soil respiration in climate change.

The evolution of the plastid genome is a key component of the evolution of the plant kingdom. The transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is a major event in the evolution of plants, and the molecular signature of this transition is not well understood. We show that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the risks posed by climate change. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the probability of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. This increase in drought risk is expected to increase further under high-emission scenarios. The results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This study provides a valuable contribution to the ongoing debate on the role of anthropogenic climate change in the recent drought in SSA. However, the results are limited to the region of interest and should be extended to other regions of the world. This will be the focus of future work.

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has revolutionized the study of materials, and the discovery of quasicrystals in the aftermath of the first nuclear explosion has revolutionized the study of time.

The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring in (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is a key reaction in photosynthesis. The mechanism of this reaction has remained a mystery for more than 60 y. This work reveals that the diiron protein AcsF is the cyclase in oxygenic phototrophs, whereas a previously unknown protein, BciE, is required in alphaproteobacteria. These findings provide a framework for understanding the evolution of this reaction, and the implications of the different classes of the enzyme are discussed. (Less)

Neuroinflammation is a major feature of neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis. Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), a model of multiple sclerosis. In this study, we found that neuroinflammation was reduced in both the early and later stages of EAE in microglia/macrophage-specific ASK1 knockout mice, whereas only the later-stage neuroinflammation was ameliorated in astrocyte-specific ASK1 knockout mice. ASK1 signaling in microglia played a major role in generating and maintaining disease, and activated astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, that further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages, in an astrocytic ASK1-dependent manner. Our findings suggest that glial ASK1 as a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of multiple sclerosis. (Show more)

California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and now includes the lowest calendar-year and 12-mo precipitation, the highest annual temperature, and the most extreme drought indicators on record. The extremely warm and dry conditions have led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that the probability of drought years has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is due to human activities.

Autism is a neurodevelopmental disorder that affects a large number of people worldwide. The etiology of autism is so complicated because it involves the effects of variants of several hundred risk genes along with the contribution of environmental factors. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we identified a converging function of autism-risk genes, which is the inability to forget. This finding provides a new perspective for the study of autism and may lead to the development of new therapeutic approaches.

This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. In doing so, it helps account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. In addition, it highlights the potential for more positive content, and suggests that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

Stormorken syndrome is a rare disease with a variety of symptoms, including bleeding diathesis, thrombocytopenia, miosis, and tubular myopathy. Here, we report that mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1, which are associated with Stormorken syndrome, result in constitutive activation of the store-operated Ca2+ channel. These findings expand our understanding of the molecular basis of Stormorken syndrome and related conditions, and suggest new therapeutic approaches for patients with Stormorken syndrome and related conditions. (Less)

The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is dependent on the internalization of aggregates, which is in turn dependent on endocytosis. We also show that the spread of aggregates is non–cell-autonomous and that the release of aggregates is dependent on fusion protein 1. These results provide insights into the mechanisms underlying the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are still largely unknown. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus, and found that this protein has the potential to inhibit the host immune system and facilitate viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting this protein. This study also provides a better understanding of the role of this protein in the bat–virus–human transmission cycle. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth, and the one-carbon unit is essential for this process. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), which is critical for the generation of the one-carbon unit. We show that this inhibitor is effective in blocking the growth of colon cancer xenografts, and that it is particularly effective in B-cell lines. We also show that the one-carbon donor formate is a potent rescue of SHMT inhibition in colon cancer cells, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. These results provide a basis for the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a neurodegenerative disease with a heterogeneous genetic basis. The disease is characterized by the presence of intracellular inclusions that contain a variety of proteins, some of which are not part of the native interaction network of the proteins that form the inclusions. Here, we show that the presence of these proteins in inclusions is not merely a subset of the native interaction partners, but rather that they are a subset of the proteins that are supersaturated in motor neurons. This suggests that the presence of inclusions in ALS is a result of a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a new perspective on the pathogenesis of ALS and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The device is fabricated from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process. The device can be deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter.

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The first flowering plants were aquatic and, in some cases, may have been the first plants to live in aquatic habitats.

The evolution of viruses is a key component in understanding the origin and evolution of life. Here we present the first ancient human parvovirus B19 (B19V) sequences, which show that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time. We also show that the recombination event that formed the most common B19V genotype 2 occurred ∼5,000 to 6,800 years ago. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Less)

Sea level is rising around the world, and the rate of rise is accelerating. This paper provides a new estimate of the rate of rise, which is higher than previous estimates. The higher rate of rise is consistent with climate models and with the observed rate of rise.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, pain prevalence has increased with age for each successive birth cohort, and that this increase has been more rapid for those born after 1950. This pattern is not seen for those with a bachelor’s degree, suggesting that the erosion of working-class life is having a negative impact on the health of the next generation.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. The application of NMR-assisted crystallography to the study of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate provides a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of the reaction species, including the location of the hydrogen atoms and the orientation of the crystallographic waters. This detailed picture of the reaction species is key to understanding the reaction pathway and the role of the cofactor and substrate in the reaction. This work highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a mechanistic view of enzyme reactions. (Less)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease with a high mortality rate. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the current standard of care is supportive care. We report the results of a study in nonhuman primates that tested the efficacy of remdesivir, an antiviral drug that has been shown to be effective against Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS)-CoV. Remdesivir was administered prophylactically or therapeutically after the onset of disease. The data presented here support the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial for the treatment of MERS. It may also be considered for the treatment of other coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study provides a proof of concept for the use of remdesivir in the treatment of coronavirus infections. The results may also have implications for the treatment of other viral diseases.

The provision of nutrients to specific symbiotic microbes is a common feature of animal-microbe interactions. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are not well understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is the trigger for the maturation of a symbiotic organ and the subsequent delivery of chitin to the luminal bacteria. This glycan is provided only at night, when the host is quiescent, and is catabolized by the symbionts to enhance their ability to produce light. This study provides a mechanism for the regulation of symbiont populations and the metabolic activity of their hosts. It also suggests that the provision of nutrients to specific symbionts may be a more general feature of animal-microbe interactions. (Less)
This study shows that it is possible to reduce suspension rates in middle schools. This is a major public health problem, and the results have implications for the future of American education.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage and is known to be involved in the etiology of cancer and other diseases. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the impact of O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (EtdT) lesions on the transcription of a lacZ reporter gene. We found that the three regioisomeric EtdT lesions can all induce transcriptional stalling, and the stalling profiles are dependent on the position of the lesion in the DNA template. In addition, we found that the stalling profiles are controlled by the pol II fidelity checkpoints. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop) that is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Taken together, this work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. This work will help us to understand the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis and the development of therapeutic strategies for cancer treatment.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe pulmonary disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. We found that sequential proteolysis of the S proteins contributes to MERS-CoV infection of human lung-derived cells, but not of other cell types. This finding may be significant for MERS-CoV virulence, because it suggests that the first S proteolytic events, which occur during virus-producing cell secretion, may be important determinants of virus tropism.

This study provides robust evidence to support the potential for simple changes to catering practices to make an important contribution to achieving more sustainable diets at the population level. The results suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering outlets by 50% could increase vegetarian meal sales by 60% or more, with little impact on overall sales and no rebound effects. This would have a significant impact on the health of the population and the environment.

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for the cell to engage the extracellular space. Here we apply a quantitative proteomics approach to reveal how the surfaceome is remodeled in a collection of six of the most prominent oncogenes, including EGFR, HER2, and KRAS, in a cell autologous fashion. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work provides a foundation for understanding the cell surface in cancer. (Less)

In the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. What are the effects of vote-by-mail? In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail is a policy that can be implemented with minimal electoral consequences. This is an important finding for scholars and policymakers alike.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global health crisis. The molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of the SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface not seen in SARS-CoV, which may be important for immune suppression and/or evasion. These results provide insights into the molecular basis of the COVID-19 pandemic and may lead to the development of therapeutics. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can lead to cerebral edema, a potentially life-threatening condition. However, the underlying mechanisms are not well understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema and neuronal apoptosis in rats, and that this is associated with an increase in the expression of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1), aquaporin-4 (AQP4), and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. We also show that the up-regulated expression of CRF, CRFR1, and AQP4 is responsible for the release of CRF, which acts on CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of AQP4 and cerebral edema. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms of cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for this condition. (Show more)

The problem of selective inference is of great importance in the era of big data. We describe some recent developments in this area and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. The goal is to provide a framework for understanding and using these methods in a way that is consistent with the principles of selective inference.

The development of vascular ECs is a critical step for the formation of functional blood vessels. However, the development of ECs has been difficult to achieve in vitro. Here, we report the generation of endothelial cells (ECs) from human fibroblasts by using a single transcription factor, Ets variant 2 (ETV2). This study provides a new approach for the generation of ECs and the formation of functional blood vessels. This approach may be useful for the treatment of vascular disorders and the regeneration of organs. Furthermore, this approach may be useful for the treatment of vascular disorders and the regeneration of organs. (Show more)
We report the discovery of a third class of RTKs, the augmentor receptors, and show that they are essential for the development of a specific type of fish pigment cells.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major public health problem. Although the molecular basis of T2D is still not fully understood, insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction are two main molecular bases yet to be further elucidated for T2D. Herein, we found that the STING protein is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency in β-cells caused glucose intolerance due to impaired insulin secretion, indicating that STING is required for normal β-cell function. These data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings may provide a better understanding of the molecular basis of T2D and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. Their genome is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates the packaging process. We identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA segments, which favors their co-packaging into the same viral particle. This interaction is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses, suggesting that it might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses.

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is associated with the disturbed flow in the blood vessels. However, the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here, we demonstrate that the activation of YAP/TAZ by the disturbed flow is critical for the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the progression of atherosclerosis. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the disturbed flow-induced atherogenesis and suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising therapeutic strategy for the treatment of atherosclerosis. This study may also provide a new perspective for the development of athero-protective strategies. (Show more)

Wildfires are a natural part of the ecosystem, but they can also be a threat to human life and property. In the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also highlight the importance of the physical environment in shaping the economic outcomes of neighborhoods.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecological method of pest control. However, the molecular targets of these repellents in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion TRP channel as a receptor of plant-derived natural repellents, which is absent in insects. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and may help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help the understanding of arthropod–plant adaptation. View Full-Text

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the rate of viral production is rapid, and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is long. We also show that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection. In the case of favipiravir, a polymerase inhibitor with activity against ZIKV, we predict a dose of 150 mg/kg given twice a day initiated at the time of infection can reduce the peak median viral load by ∼3 logs and shorten the time to undetectable median viral load by ∼2 d. These results provide insights into the potential of antiviral treatment for ZIKV infection. (Show more)

Coral reefs are among the most diverse and valuable ecosystems on Earth. However, they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors. In this study, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This process is a direct consequence of the metabolic interactions between the coral host and its algal symbionts and may therefore be a general feature of endosymbiotic relationships.

The intestinal epithelium is a barrier to the environment and a hub for the interaction with the microbiome. In this study, we show that the loss of BMP signaling in the epithelium leads to the development of intestinal tumors, which in turn, trigger a regenerative response in the microbiome and promote tumor growth. We also identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. Our results highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. They also provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer treatment. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response of individual patients to treatment is highly variable. We show that the expression of a receptor, ROR1, is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, which enhances the expression of genes involved in the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or B lymphoma Mo-MLV insertion region 1 homolog (BMI1). We also show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab reduces the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. This approach may be particularly effective in patients with triple-negative breast cancer, which is associated with a poor prognosis. (Read more)

The start of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is often attributed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies and subsequent climate impacts. We show that the start of this event is instead linked to a series of massive volcanic eruptions, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and, in turn, to a change in Southern Hemisphere climate.

Freshwater fisheries are an essential source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which can be used to assess the impacts of fishing on biodiversity and food security. We find that fishing is most intense in regions where rivers are already under stress from other human activities. This suggests that conservation efforts should focus on reducing the impacts of pollution and habitat degradation, rather than on eliminating fishing. Our data can also be used to target investments in fisheries management, which are urgently needed to ensure the sustainability of this important ecosystem service.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge. The aqueous energy storage devices are promising for this purpose, but the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the adult nervous system. In the mammalian CNS, however, the regenerative capacity of neurons is severely compromised, and regeneration is not possible in the peripheral nervous system. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This discovery provides a platform for the discovery of novel factors and signaling pathways that regulate the regenerative capacity of the adult CNS. Moreover, our study suggests that the mammalian CNS may be more regenerative than previously thought.

The process of recombination is central to the evolution of the genome. Here, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, which is similar to that in yeast and mice.

The resting state of the brain is a complex and poorly understood phenomenon. Here, we show that the metabolic activity of the brain can be used to identify and validate the organization of the resting state. This approach provides a direct and objective method for the study of the resting state of the brain, which is of fundamental importance for understanding the organization of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is required for efficient translation and is also involved in mRNA export and stability. Here we report the discovery of a second 5′ modification, the nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) group. We show that NAD-RNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in yeast. This finding suggests that NAD+ may play a role in the regulation of gene expression in eukaryotes.

We found that DNA methylation at specific loci in blood cells from people with diabetes are different at baseline vs. long-term follow-up, and that these differences are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for the metabolic memory phenomenon, the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The role of fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) in TNBC has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Alcohol dependence is a brain disorder, but the mechanisms underlying this are not fully understood. In this study, we found that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects developed gut leakiness, which was associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also had altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study may also have implications for the treatment of other psychiatric disorders. (PsycINFO Dataset)

The flavor of tomato fruit is a result of the production of a large number of volatile chemicals. These volatiles are produced by a variety of metabolic pathways, including the biosynthesis of nitrogenous compounds. The biosynthesis of these compounds is not known, and thus the origin of the nitrogenous flavor compounds in tomato fruit is unknown. Here we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit.

We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. This is important because temperature is one of the most profound threats to the functional integrity of the Earth’s ecosystems. We also show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. This is important because temperature is one of the most profound threats to the functional integrity of the Earth’s ecosystems.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure in the mammalian brain, playing a role in spatial navigation and memory. However, the organization of its neurons is still poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which are thought to be essential for spatial navigation, are organized separately from other neurons. This suggests that the organization of the MEC is more complex than previously thought. Our results will help to elucidate the function of the MEC and its role in spatial navigation. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Flowering is a complex process, which is regulated by a variety of environmental and internal signals. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) is able to synchronize the flowering of host and parasite plants. This study illustrates the importance of FTs in interplant communication and the role of FTs in the regulation of flowering time.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. We show that striatonigral fibers originating in striosomes form highly unusual arborizations that target bundles of ventrally extending dopamine-containing dendrites and clusters of their parent nigral cell bodies. These clustered cell bodies in turn project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, these striosome–dendron formations, here termed “striosome–dendron bouquets,” likely represent subsystems with the nigro–striato–nigral loop that are affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. This work provides a new perspective on the organization of the dopamine systems of the brain and their potential role in health and disease.

We are all familiar with the feeling of “clicking” with someone. But how do we know when two people are “clicking”? We show that the speed at which people respond to each other is a robust and sufficient signal of connection.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for the generation of the heart rate. The SAN is a highly specialized cell, and its function is regulated by a number of factors. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a regulator of the SAN, and that it is expressed in the specialized cardiomyocytes of the SAN.

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, the role of Si in plant resistance against insect herbivores has not been well established. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is associated with an increase in the accumulation of Si and the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. These results suggest that Si may be used as a biopesticide to protect rice from insect herbivores. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We demonstrate that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is a key regulator of the lipidome in murine macrophages.

Language processing is a complex cognitive function that is thought to be supported by a sustained increase in neural activity. However, there is evidence that short-term synaptic facilitation may also play a role in memory. Here we propose a model of memory that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and can support the binding of linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. Here, we report the successful delivery of siRNA to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructure are the key design parameters for the successful delivery of biomolecules to plants. This work provides a platform for the delivery of biomolecules to plants and also establishes the design parameters for the successful delivery of biomolecules to plants. This work will be of interest to the plant biology community and also to the broader nanotechnology community.

Eutrophication is a major threat to the health of lakes and coastal ecosystems worldwide. In the United States, the majority of nutrient loading to lakes is from nonpoint sources, such as runoff from agricultural fields and urban areas. However, the role of small streams in driving coastal nutrient inputs has been largely overlooked. We show that small streams can be a significant source of nutrients to large lakes, and that their nutrient loads are often high for their size. This suggests that nutrient management efforts to reduce coastal eutrophication should focus on small streams, as well as larger tributaries. Our findings have important implications for the management of nutrient loading to lakes and coastal ecosystems worldwide.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in the presence of a strong environmental forcing. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing.

This paper offers a new perspective on the mechanisms of action of NMDA-receptor antibodies, which are currently the only treatment for autoimmune encephalitis. We show that these antibodies can change the dynamics of the brain, which in turn can lead to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. This work offers a new way to think about the mechanisms of action of these antibodies and may help to guide the development of new treatments.

The history of Earth’s climate is a history of abrupt warming events. These events are often associated with changes in the carbon cycle. However, the history of carbon perturbations during abrupt warming events is not well understood. Here, we present a study of an abrupt warming event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that this event was associated with a large injection of organic matter–derived carbon into the ocean and that this event was linked to a global warming and anoxia of the deep ocean. This study provides insights into the history of carbon perturbations during abrupt warming events and into the potential impacts of such events on the Earth system.

Certification of palm oil production is a major policy tool for reducing deforestation. However, the impact of certification on deforestation has not been evaluated in a way that allows for a clear assessment of its effectiveness. We show that certification is associated with a reduction in deforestation, but that most certified areas still contain substantial amounts of forest. This suggests that certification is not yet having a large impact on deforestation in Indonesia, and that broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is not yet having a large impact on deforestation in Indonesia.

The exocyst complex is involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential for the functioning of all kingdoms of life. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. In this study, we discovered a small molecule that inhibits the exocyst complex in plants and humans. This study provides a valuable tool for studying the regulation of the exocyst complex and a potential target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in the evolution of animals, and the sex of an individual is often a key determinant of reproductive success. In many species, sex is determined by a single genetic locus, resulting in two sexes. In other species, sex is determined by multiple interacting alleles, resulting in more than two genotypic sexes. Here we show that the sex of a fish can be determined by a single allele in some individuals and by multiple alleles in others, resulting in four possible sex classes. This form of polygenic sex determination can result in modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, which can be influenced by the acquisition of a new sex determiner. These results provide a framework for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of sex determination alleles in populations. (Less)

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by a variety of free radicals, reactive oxygen species, and reactive carbonyl species. These species are generated by the metabolism of vitamin A and its derivatives, and by the photodegradation of visual pigments. The retina is also challenged by the accumulation of lipid-derived reactive intermediates, which are generated by the photooxidation of lipofuscin, a pigment that accumulates in the retinal pigment epithelium. We show that the levels of iron in the retina, which is a key player in the generation of reactive intermediates, can influence the levels of these reactive intermediates. These findings have implications for the understanding of the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration and other retinal diseases. (Read more)

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is central to understanding the structure of food webs. However, the evolution of predator specialization has been considered an evolutionary dead end. Here we show that siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians, have evolved to capture different prey types using the same structure, and that these changes are linked to the evolution of the structure and function of the prey-capturing system. Our findings help to understand the evolution of specialization and morphological innovation in predators, and contribute to the study of the evolution of food webs.

The human hand is a complex and highly evolved structure. The evolution of the human hand is a key topic in the study of human evolution. This study provides the earliest evidence for the evolution of a key feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process.

Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth, and the one-carbon unit is essential for this process. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), which is critical for the generation of the one-carbon unit. We have also identified a metabolic vulnerability of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL), which is a particularly aggressive form of cancer. This work provides a foundation for the development of a class of drugs that target the one-carbon unit, and may be useful in the treatment of cancer.

Deforestation is a major driver of environmental change and is often blamed for the loss of biodiversity and ecosystem services. However, it is also a major driver of food and nutrition security, particularly in rural areas of low- and middle-income countries. This study shows that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this impact is exacerbated by fragmentation of forests. This study has important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the need for more research on the role of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets.

Mechanization has been a key driver of the Green Revolution, which has led to the expansion of food production and the reduction of hunger and poverty. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We hypothesize that the paradox of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction, including the roaming of sauropods, may have guided the development of ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, that guided these prehistoric giants. This study highlights the need for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. (Less)
